title: Before 1 December 2020, will Mohammed bin Salman cease to be the Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia?
possible_answers: Yes, by becoming the King of Saudi Arabia
Yes, without becoming the King of Saudi Arabia
preds: There's got to be a calculator that prevents Brier score "sniping" like this, right?  Just an idle forecast while looking around.

- G20 has concluded without a formal transition of power announcement. 
- Unless the King dies in the next 48 hours MBS will remain prince.
No public reports of changes to the king's health.  Thus, I'm decrementing slightly the chance that MBS becomes king in the next few days.
No recent reports on the King's health, so looks like MBS will have to wait.

I have changed my forecast from 80% to 100% no. I think he will be in this middle ground for at least a little while longer. MBS reportedly met with the Prime Minister of Israel on Sunday "The Saudi's deny this". He will be a key player in the Middle East in the future in my opinion but only as the Crown prince or the moment.
Clock is ticking with no intervening effents
Not likely in the next few days.
G20 Summit is now over with nothing heard about MBS moving up.  Since President Trump has not conceded the election yet, 1 December will come and go with MBS still the Crown Prince.
I don't give him long with a Biden Presidency though.

- November G20 will be virtual, reduces the ability to showcase MBS.
- Momentum against Saudi Arabia Human Rights violations are growing which does not support MBS announcement prior to December 1.  https://www.aljazeera.com/opinions/2020/11/10/saudi-arabias-image-building-efforts-suffered-another-set-back/

With Dec 1 now only 2 weeks away, I'm updating my forecast with a reduced likelihood of MBS becoming king.  The main wild card that I was keeping an eye on was the Nov 21-22 G-20 Summit, which my colleague speculated MBS would use as an opportunity to maneuver himself into being declared King, so he could preside over the summit.  However, not seeing any reason to indicate that that will happen.  This article from late September in fact indicates that King Salman intends to preside over the Summit.  https://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1202358.shtml
A quick google scan of news regarding King Salman's health status doesn't reveal any new developments that indicate that his health is any more fragile than usual, so presumably he will survive over the next couple of weeks.

Revised 20201115 1% should King Salman die before 1 Dec 2020. I've not seen or heard any report or comment that the king is in ill health and it is highly unlikely he would succumb to an assassination in the next 2 weeks but there is always the small probability of that.

Decrementing for time remaining and King looks and sounds to be in good health.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OLKtnaKU9fk&feature=emb_logo https://www.msn.com/en-ae/news/other/saudi-arabia-s-king-salman-opens-8th-shoura-council-session/ar-BB1aVqDm?pfr=1
"Comments made in the presence of the Crown Prince" so all indications Crown Prince remains in good standing in the royal family. However Bahraini Prime Minister, aged 84, just passed away without notice so some small chance.
Only three weeks to go and no significant change in the situation as far as I can tell.  Increasing my 'no' vote 2%.

Still no news on the king's health...so upgrading my "no" vote 1%.  One interesting development is the potential civil prosecution of MBS over the Khassogi murder and treatment of one of his former intelligence leaders.  Still, I don't see that process playing out in the next four weeks, or frankly, having much bearing on whether MBS remains the CP.  Still, interesting nevertheless.

death and abdication very unlikely within the next month.
Ascention as well.
Adjusting due to the passage of time. No news media updates on King Salman's health.
King continues to be more visible, this indicates health is okay.

Will put it out there and say the authors of this Question has been weighted into the crowd forecast. If this was Foxes ask then NO would be higher. That said, probably will move on from forecasting individual older persons health outcomes truth be told.
Still no news to change my forecast here.  It seems highly likely that MBS will still be the crown prince on 1 Dec barring a sudden change to the King's health.
Forecast adjusted due to theta decay (i.e. decrease in time to expiration).
Significant change in my probability forecast due to updated news and inclusion of crowd forecast.
Getting closer to the date with no political action to remove MBS
1 Dec is coming up rather quickly, but my current forecast seems to be rather aggressive relative to smart people, so I'm holding steady.
Will need US and Israel to manage transition - both have hands full

- Assuming the only article referenced by other forecasters is true and MBS announces assession plans at the G-20 (20 Nov), I think it is unlikely that a formal ceremony takes place prior to 1 DEC. I can not find any data on how this works, but it seems unlikely to turn around this event in less than 10 days. 
- The current monarchy has only abdicated 1 in 7 and not since 1964 due to internal conflict which has since been eliminated. 
-
Adjusting due to the passage of time. No news media updates on King Salman's health.

I thought I’d done a forecast on this previously, but apparently not.  So;
Outside View:  
Regarding the possibility of MBS becoming king due to the death or incapacitation of his father---
King Salman is 84, has dementia, and had gallbladder surgery in July, although he seems to have recovered from that and there don’t appear to be any new reports of adverse health of the king.  
@jtrusz had a good outside view analysis of the general stats regarding longevity of the Saudi male population, the typical length of a monarch’s reign, etc… following that analysis, I’d say that it seems not likely that the king would die or hand over power in the next 6 weeks.
Some teammates wondered if the King could die of COVID.  I assume that the King lives in a pretty protected bubble, so I doubt that he’d be likely to catch it.  If he did catch it, though, according to my research he could die from it in as little as 2 weeks, given his age.  So in other words between now and Dec 1 would be enough of a time window for Covid to kill the king--- assuming he caught it in the first place.
Inside View:
On the question of whether MBS might try to overthrow his father---
A classmate who is a Saudi national remarked that there has never been a coup in Saudi Arabia, and it is “culturally inconceivable” for a son to usurp a father.  So unless MBS is willing to break some very strong cultural norms (and some would say he already has), seems unlikely that he would brazenly grab power from his father in a coup-like scenario. 
This classmate predicts that MBS will stay Crown Prince because things are going well in the country, and a coup is unlikely especially if there is stability and prosperity in Saudi.
Here is an analysis from a State Department colleague who is an expert on the Mid East:
“There was some speculation earlier in the year that MBS was clearing the decks (eg detaining/sacking royal family rivals and critics) to accede to the throne around the G20 Summit later this year:  (https://www.middleeasteye.net/news/exclusive-saudi-crown-prince-plans-become-king-novembers-g20-summit). “That hasn't remained in the media much later in the year after the pandemic took hold, and Covid may have thrown a wrench into his plans - a royal leadership transition could be a lot in the midst of a pandemic and pretty far-reaching cultural reforms.   “So I think "No" is probably the most likely outcome, but there's also a bit of a generational shift going on in the region right now with the Abraham Accords seeming to herald new relationships and priorities.  And the Saudis love Trump, so a Biden win could potentially push them to empower a new monarch to work with a new US admin they see as suspect.  So I don't think it's as farfetched as it might seem.   “I would probably guess something like 35 percent Yes, by becoming king, 5 percent Yes without becoming king, and 60 percent No. “ My take:  It’s obvious that MBS plans to become King, and has been maneuvering to make that happen.  The insider knowledge I was able to glean does not seem to think that MBS will become King by natural or political means in the short term.  The time horizon to Dec. 1 is pretty short, reducing the likelihood of events that would elevate MBS to the kingship, but the one big wild card between now and Dec 1 that could play a role is the Nov 21-22 G20 Summit in Riyadh.  I will keep an eye on that event as a potential influencer in the outcome.
No significant change to the King's health.
Decrementing as no indication position of power is threatened and no negative news on health of King.

I'm hearing nothing more about MBS' ambitions or how he might achieve them. I'm trying to think like MBS.  He has already done things that I would consider unthinkable, like detain dozens of relatives in a posh hotel, and release them only after they had been forced to divest themselves of certain assets:  a move which seems to me to have increased the number of his enemies and motivated them to plot against him, rather than consolidate his power, but what do I know?  So, my lack of imagination should not guide my forecast. However, I also have had a difficult time figuring out how he could become king without the current king dying first--the odds of which are low in the next 2 months. I can, however, imagine his enemies uniting against him. @pstamp
Nothing significant has changed and the deadline is getting closer. As the US election draws near, I don't expect many countries to make extreme changes until they see how the U.S. will play out.
Adjusting for passage of time.  No meaningful updates.  G-20 participation is interesting, but irrelevant
With the time remaining in this forecast and no indication of health of current King being in question it is more likely the Crown Prince will remain in current position.
Despite the unpopularity of MBS outside of Saudi Arabia, it appears the only way MBS will not be Crown Prince before December would be to become King.
No changes in the current King's health, which may drive MBS to become King.

- MBS consolidation of power makes trial for the death of the journalist unlikely at this point and I have adjusted removal from crown prince downward due to the remaining timeframe.
- No updated medical issues have been reported
No new information pertaining to the king's health or internal threats to MBS.  With about 8 weeks until the end of the forecast window, it appears MBS will still be the Crown Prince on 1 Dec.
Readjusted because after further reading, Salman's father the King may very well remain beyond 1 December if Salman's announcement of his Kingship doesn't occur at the counsel in Nov.
with DAWN, there is now a formal institution with a martyr to fight against.

Mohamed bin Salman (MBS) has consolidated the court, intelligence agencies, and the Wahabist clerics, behind his agenda through cajoling and more frequently, purging. MBS' arrest of his cousin and rival Mohamed bin Nayef (MBN) and Mr. Nayef's father have shown without a doubt that the military and intelligence establishment is in complete support of MBS and his agenda. MBN was a respected and feared head of intelligence services, a prominent and influential member of the court, an advocate of the conservative ideals espoused by the clerics, and enjoyed strong ties with the US intelligence and military communities. If MBS can pull a move like this on a guy like MBN, he has all but ensured his eventual succession to the throne. Last note: I think Salman bin AbdulAziz has a couple more years left in the tank.
I have not been persuaded by any arguments that would support the first of second bin in this timeframe.

Extremely low probability of him abdicating his position as a crown prince without becoming a king. His current hold on the country is pretty powerful. Unless we are talking about another Arab spring, this is unlikely. It could also be true if he were to die and given his age and current health, it would have to be an assassination. Pretty low probability. His chance of becoming king is high but for that to happen in the next 2 months is less probable considering King Salman took throne in 2015. Given his advanced age or some kind of assasination attempt or a coup, I would rate this a bit higher probability.

I still firmly believe that MBS will be the next king of SA, but I don't see that happening in the next 64 days.  Based simply on the time since making my first forecast on the question (~77 days from the end of the forecast window), I've upped my overall "no" and decremented by two yes answers accordingly.  The critical "x factor" for me would be another health scare for the king, which may or may not be openly reported by the relatively authoritarian regime.

As others have pointed out, the current King is old, but in good health. Very low base rate for the death of a King. A change in the head of state is often a long process, and this Q only has 2 months on it.

The King is still healthy enough despite his recent gall bladder troubles. Mohammed bin Salman is a hard-line autocrat that the other hard-liners in Saudi Arabia still find satisfactory despite his reforms. The only variable is his relationship with Trump and the West and, as such, things are likely to change in Saudi only if Trump loses the U.S. election in November. If Trump wins, bin Salman stays right where he's at unless the King dies.

- Low health risk for the king- view this as one of the only plausible ways for MBS to gain the throne. 
- Highly implausible to be ousted by other means.

Since MBS has assumed the Crown Prince's tile, he took a ruthless course of action to eliminate all opposition to his power by imprisoning followers of Bin Nayef on corruption charges and by assassination of a critic/journalist, to name some examples. 
It would hardly be possible for whatever remaining marginal opposition to depose MBS, but they may have a shot if the succession (if King Salman dies) turns chaotic and foreign forces intervene on behalf of former crown prince Mohammed Bin Nayef who has support in the West. However, King Salman has already had health issues, meaning that MBS is likely prepared against any attempts to sabotage his formal coronation.

-Saudi dissidents have launched a mission to spark the transition to democracy and oust de-facto leader Mohammed bin Salman.
-The 84-year-old king, delivers a speech to UN this week demonstrating he retains oversight of high-level policies despite the immense powers amassed by his son, the crown prince
Current king is almost 85 so it is possible he will die or suffer a incapacitating illness within the next 2 months - though it's a small chance.

There are 65 days remaining before this question ends. Changes of state are often long periods of equilibrium followed by rapid changes. We seem to be in the long equilibrium phase. I'll give it a 1% per month of happening.
Only a little more than two months away and not much change?

King Salman at 84, 2 months post Gal bladder surgery is in reasonable health, implying a high degree of probability in continuing to live for a few months.
MBS is the defacto ruler of SA and continues to strenghten his grip on power. Pandemic pressure on oil revenue, global outcry on human rights should do little to change the power trajectory in SA for MBS.

Anger against the government is growing among the people. Regional countries do not respect Saudi Arabia as much as before. If Trump loses the next election, it is almost certain that Mohammed bin Salman will face a huge crisis.  A group of dissidents has launched an opposition party. King upset over recent Israeli deal.

The King is 84 years old. December 31 is his birthday. Right now is 25 Sept. The question deadline is 1 December So what is his probability of surviving 2m and 1w?
Actuarial table shows chances of death in 1Y for an 84 year old is 8.8% and chance of death for an 85 year old is 9.7%.
https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html
9.7% per year is closer because he is nearly 85 now, but he is very wealthy so can afford much better health care. He also doesn't drink or smoke obviously.  So lets go with 9% chance of death per year. We also notice probability changed by about 10% over a year so a linear interpolation of probability over 2 months will be accurate to about 2%, considerably greater than errors over guessing his current health. So this moves us to 9/12*2.2 = 1.65% of death. We also know he had an apparently successful gall bladder operation in July this year. He isn't dead so the operation itself didn't kill him, and a gall bladder issue doesn't seem to be a typical terminal problem. So this provides as much evidence of bad health as it provides evidence of access to best health treatments money can buy. So, 2% chance of death. There is also a possibility of the king handing over to his successor.  A quick glance at a single article
https://www.brookings.edu/blog/markaz/2017/06/23/will-saudi-arabias-king-salman-abdicate/ The king seems to have had early dementure in 2017 (now is 3 years later).
The problem though for abdication is there is no obvious motive. The Crown Prince already does pretty much all of the daily governing, and if the King wanted the prince to do even more, he could just give the Crown Prince more powers without abdicating. Further, the Crown Prince can get a "get out of jail free" card by the King abdicating after a disaster and handing over to the Crown Prince, as long as the Crown Prince isn't too complicit, in which case nothing lost. But the thing that convinced me is there is no historical precedent for abdication other than down the barrel of a gun. There is no obvious threat of coups, or revolutions, political resistance or constitutional crisis. Nor is abdication common in the region at large. So the chances of abdication are almost zero. It is possible there was a long-standing plan to groom the crown prince for being King and it just so happens to happen between now and December. But even if that was the plan, the probability of the abdication happening then is still low, as it's just 2 months and a week. But the clincher, as per the article, is that no deputy crown prince has been appointed yet, which seems to be an urgent requirement for a planned handover. I'll go with 1% for abdication, which I add to the 2% chance of death.
The probability of The Crown Prince being fired is zero, because the King loves him and despite the anger by the West about the killing of a single journalist, those in the region barely bat an eyelid. And if he was going to be fird, he would have been fired long ago. Nor does it seem him not being made a king is likely. The Crown Prince has far too much power for rivals to have a serious chance. Weaknesses: I am very reliant on just one report from the Brookings institute. But I have a job to do too, so can't do everything.  That being said, the Brookings institute is "ranked as the first-most influential and first in credibility among 27 think tanks considered. Yet "Brookings and its researchers are not so concerned, in their work, in affecting the ideological direction of the nation" and rather tend "to be staffed by researchers with strong academic credentials". So it is about as strong a source as you can get. Politically independent and expert.  Further the author is Bruce Riedel. He has prolific experience and expertise on these things frequently required at the very highest levels. So if he is good enough for both the PM of the UK and the President of the US, he's good enough for me. His closeness to Barak Obama gives me some pause, given Obama's insane and terrible foreign policy ideas. However, these policies seem mostly Obama's personally, and I see no sign Bruce Riedel "bought" Obama's "strategic patience" nonsense. So I have no reason to doubt his word. It's about one of the best views on this it is possible to get. Caveat: Western experts in the Middle East tend to be way out in terms of understanding that region. But this article seems sensible, and none of the regional quirks that send so many Western experts down the wrong direction seem to apply for this question. And I see no evidence Bruce Riedel has gone down that road. My forecast then follows.
The chances of the King dying or stepping aside in the next 3 months (regardless of recent health concerns) is slim.
2% chance King Salman dies. Doubling that to account for MBS acceding
Fine tuning, there are 3 months for something to happen.

"A group of Saudi dissidents exiled in Britain, the U.S and elsewhere announced the launch of an opposition party on Wednesday, the first organised political resistance under King Salman’s rule.
Saudi Arabia is an absolute monarchy that does not tolerate any political opposition, but the formation of the National Assembly Party on the anniversary of the kingdom’s founding comes amid a growing state crackdown on dissent and freedom of expression.
[...]
Saudi Arabia has long faced international criticism over its human rights record.
That has intensified since Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman was named heir to the Saudi throne in June 2017.
In particular, the grizly October 2018 murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul sparked unprecedented international scrutiny of the kingdom’s human rights record.
The global fallout over the murder tarnished the crown prince’s carefully cultivated reputation as a reformer, casting a shadow over his ambitious attempts to modernise the conservative kingdom’s economy and society.
In a radical makeover of the kingdom, the 35-year-old Prince Mohammed clipped the powers of the once-feared clerical establishment, lifted the world’s only ban on women drivers, reopened cinemas and allowed mixed-gender entertainment.
But the social reforms have been in lockstep with political repression, party members said.
The party’s creation is a “very long overdue move”, said Alaoudh, whose father Salman al-Awda, a religious cleric, faces the death penalty after he was arrested in September 2017.
The party seeks to protect the country from “upheaval and absolute dictatorship and pave the way for democracy in a peaceful transition,“ Alaoudh told AFP. — AFP" https://www.thesundaily.my/world/saudi-dissidents-launch-opposition-party-amid-repression-YD4225450

One thought (1) by @A356 changed my mind by 5%: Seeing MBS as de facto King, why should he hurry the formal recognition instead of strengthening his actual power behind the scenes even more? He has the option of ascending with his fathers blessing. Either expressly by his father's abdication or implied by his father's death. Both ways would be a way to have a process giving more legitimacy. Both ways allow for more power now and pride later. MBS behaviour was strategic in such regards, I expect it to stay so. (1) https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1141584
@A356 provided a concise overview of the situation.

Very good info on Mohammed bin Salman's (MBS) rise to power: https://observer.com/2019/01/how-saudi-arabia-crown-prince-mbs-rose-to-power/#:~:text=Just%20three%20months%20into%20his,old%20nephew%2C%20Mohammad%20bin%20Nayef. https://www.businessinsider.com/saudi-arabia-mbs-final-threats-saad-aljabri-mohammed-bin-nayef-2020-8 Just three months into his reign, King Salman (MBS's father and current King) dismissed his successor apparent, Crown Prince Muqrin, who was already 70 at the time and gave the crown prince title to his 56-year-old nephew, Mohammad bin Nayef, a “magnificent seven” prince, and he was young enough to secure the power for another couple of decades.
However, it turned out that Nayef was not good enough. What King Salman really wanted was for his own son, MBS, to carry on the throne.
In June 2017, Nayef gave up his claim to the throne to his cousin, MBS, who had just turned 31. Since then, MBS has ruthlessly tried to eliminate all his domestic threats to consolidate power. Which he has achieved very successfully.  On 31 Jul 2020 King Salman left the hospital after a 10-day stay where the 84-year-old underwent surgery to remove his gall bladder [1]. It was not life-threatening but his deteriorating health will undoubtedly hamper his ability to be King, even if that just means a few public appearances.  MBS may want to become King before the November election due to his relatively good relationship with the Trump administration compared to a future Biden one, giving his 'promotion' more legitimacy. (amongst several criticisms, Biden promised to end the sale of US weapons to Saudi Arabia for its war in Yemen). However, he is already the King in every way apart from name. Becoming King will not change much for him and he may want to wait until the death or abdication of his father out of respect. If his father chooses when he abdicates, it could happen next week or in 2023. But, his health and age mean it will probably be sooner rather than later. Seems very possible before 1 Dec due to the US elections and his fathers health. A situation where the answer is 'Yes, without becoming the King of Saudi Arabia' is very unlikely.  [1] https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/07/31/saudi-king-salman-leaves-hospital-after-gall-bladder-surgery/#:~:text=King%20Salman%20was%20admitted%20to,bladder%2C%20according%20to%20state%20media.&text=There%20has%20been%20much%20speculation,in%20line%20to%20the%20throne.

KSA is hosting the G20 summit.  MBS has suggested he'd like to be king by then.  I ask myself what hints there might be that something was afoot, and think maybe none because KSA is not open and transparent.  So, I see no smoke, which makes me nervous.   I'm reminding myself that the status quo is always the most likely outcome, and that's what the crowd believes, too.  I'm losing nerve and increasing "No".

Certainly death of the King would bring him the crown, however, there is no public knowledge that indicates the kings lifespan is only a couple of more months.  Salman has solidly positioned himself to ascend to the throne when the king dies.
With an outside perspective.  Considering how likely it is that the King leaves his position ether from death or mental capacity I am adjusting my forcase.

I don't believe external international pressures will impact Mohammed bin Salman becoming the King of Saudi Arabia.  So to me, the quest is will the vacancy become available in this timeframe.  I don't know much about the health of the current King but I feel if his health was in bad share I would have heard about the risk of his death.  Based on the risk of his death I say 55% possibility.

King Salman is 84 years old and was recently hospitalized for inflammation of the gal bladder. News media also report that he suffers from Alzheimer's disease (anonymous sources). Nevertheless, there is no reporting to indicate he is on death's door. His father, Ibn Saud, who died in the 1950s lived to be 78. Given the king's access to the best medical care, it seems unlikely he will die before December 1, 2020. Media reports of factions within the royal family seeking to oust the king go back to at least 2015. However, MBS' consolidation of power seems to have removed or greatly reduced that threat. Based on the above, it seems unlikely King Salman will die/be deposed before December 1 or that MBS will be deposed before December 1.

with perception of probability of Trump's loss growing in the region (1), a consolidation during Trump's Presidency might seem to be more likely to succeed for MbS; Him using the pretence of ill health now rather than actually waiting until a natural succession would accur, would give the added benefit of his knowing quite precisely about the powers that be instead of having to speculate about the power-balances in the future (be it democratic powers or re-emerged family members). (1) https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/saudi-era-200921100612533.html

The actual political drive to remove MBS seems to significantly outweigh the actual actions or intent of the regime to do so. The death of King Salman is more credible, with persistent media reports to suggest he is in poor health.  But I wonder how many of these reports actually originate from Saudi Arabia's or MBS's rivals.

- 4 of 6 Transitions were due to death by natural causes.
- Sons of Ibn Saud are considered to have primary claim on the throne of Saudi Arabia
- The shortest reign since 1972 has been 7 years, the current king is at 5 years.
- Oldest King was 92, current 84 and has damensia. 
- Average life expectancy in Saudi Arabia is 75
- Average life expectancy of top 1% of earners is 87
- There are reports China is enriching uranium in Saudi Arabia (strong partner support of King)
- Oil prices continue to stay at multi-year lows jeapordizing MBS status
- 7 Sep MBS another purge to align his position for the thrown.

I am making some assumptions based on the phrasing of the questions; 1) yes, by becoming the king of Saudi Arabia - means that King Salman passes or steps down 2) yes, without becoming the king of Saudi Arabia - means that something happens to MbS (killed, imprisoned, replaces as crowned prince) 3) No - means no change from current status I think the second condition is below 1% probability. If the murder of Khashoggi couldn't bring him down, then I fail to see any indicators that something else will - especially since MbS spared the heads of his security apparatus from scrutiny. I think that the most likely scenario (on a relative basis) is the passing of King Salman. Its hard to find what his specific health issue was regarding his gallbladder, but the most common gallbladder issue invovles a cholecystectomy, which carries a .1-.7  mortality rate post surgery [1].  King Salman is currently 84 years old in a country where the life expectancy is 75.22 years [2] There are ways to calculate specific mortality based on a specific age using Bayes.... I used this instead because I'm lazy right now (I'll try to learn the math for Bayes mortality calculator later): https://media.nmfn.com/tnetwork/lifespan/#13 Based on the slight increased risk post-surgery for his gallbladder, I'm assessing a 1% risk of death (which would satisfy condition 1), and thus 99% for condition 3. [1]https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4333785/#:~:text=In%20population%2Dbased%20studies%2C%20the,between%200.1%25%20and%200.7%25.&text=Mortality%20rates%20were%20not%20substantially,a%20laparoscopic%20cholecystectomy%20(LC). [2] https://www.macrotrends.net/countries/SAU/saudi-arabia/life-expectancy

King Salman underwent gallbladder surgery in July of this year and was reported to have a good recovery.  He's 84 and there are lots of rumors that he's in poor health including overnight (21 Sep) social media chatter that he's in critical health.  The King has removed all threats to his son, Crown Prince Salman, and consolidated power under his son, so there's little chance the Crown Prince won't become the next King.  The only question is when.
I believe the timeline is not long enough

While King Salman's health isn't great the likelihood of a sudden succession of power in the next 2 months is slim to none. What's more almost as unlikely (and barely worth a percentage point) is MBS losing his position as Crown Prince. Given it's been years since the murder of Khashoggi with no impact on his position, this gives me reason to believe that the only behavior that will result in the loss of his position would be going directly against the King's wishes.

While MBS has made some significant mistakes in recent years, including Yemen, he has kept a close watch over succession threats and carried out his most recent purge only two weeks ago.  This tight control combined with his loyalty to King Salman, make it unlikely that he would be unseated at Crown Prince in the near-term.   Although 84-years-old, King Salman's health is currently stable, so it would also be unlikely that MBS would become King in this period.
The risk of the King contracting COVID-19 increases chances of MBS moving from Crown Prince to King.  Barring that, anticipate status-quo.

HM MBS will become king when the time arrives. His father health is ok for his age, so probably later https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/07/saudi-arabia-king-salman-successful-gallbladder-surgery-200723132129155.html

While MBS has made many enemies, it is not clear to me from my brief reading on recent events that there is a clear and strong opposition to him. He has made prescient moves to limit his opposition, and control over security or military services does not appear to be in doubt. His father is in poor health, but barring any changes or updates, I see no reason to assume he will not last through September.  The disagreement over recognizing Israel could presenting interesting questions, particularly if more of the population (particularly those in the elite is against MBS on this.

Prince Mohammed bin Salman has been extremely loyal to his father, King Salman. When King Salman was believed to be sick, MBS supported him. The key threats to MBS becoming the next king after his father passes are Prince Ahmad and Prince Mohammad bin Nayef; were both placed in jail for treason in March. The arrest sent a message to all that speaking ill of the current leadership will not end well. The only way MBL leaves his current position is to become king because his father died (he is 85 and 2020 has bin a terrible year).

Since becoming Crown Prince in June 2017, Bin Salman would have been Crown Prince for approx. 3 years and 5 months to December 2020. 
Of the 11 previous Crown Princes, 6 exceeded 3 years and 5 months as Crown Prince ->
X = Bin Salman Crown Prince for longer than 3 years and 5 months = 55% = 6/11
Y = Bin Salman Crown Prince for less than 3 years and 5 months = 45% = 5/11 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crown_Prince_of_Saudi_Arabia Looking at the 5 who didn't exceed this time (2 Resigned, 1 Deposed, 1 Died, 1 Became King), I don't consider Bin Salman either resigning, being deposed or dying a likely scenario so will reduce these possibilities by 0.25  ->
Yes without becoming King = 9% = Y * (4/5) * 0.25 While his father is elderly, it is a short time before December 2020 so will leave it unchanged ->
Yes by becoming King = 9% = Y * (1/5) Therefore I will update X ->
X = 82% = 100% - (Yes without becoming King + Yes by becoming King)

84 yr old King Salman's health isn't great (just had his gallbladder removed), but there doesn't appear to be a health crisis on the immediate (pre 1 Dec) horizon.  That, of course, could change.  MbS could be forced out of his position based on international reaction to his treatment of rivals, etc but I view this as very unlikely unless the G20 puts immense pressure on the king to remove the crown prince in the lead up to November's summit in Riyadh.  Even still, I view monarchs as mostly disinclined to bow to external pressure on internal politics and human rights.  The most likely outcome is that MbS will continue to be the crown prince on 1 Dec.

According to report in Muslim Times, the Saudi crown prince is working to eliminate all obstacles to the throne before this year’s G20 summit in Riyadh in November. I couple this with peace overtures between Arab states and Israel gaining steam, and MBS statement there can be no peace with Israel until the Palestinian question is settled. MBS cannot exert control over foreign affairs without being head of state. I would score the prospect of ascendency higher but blowback continues with Woodward's new book, Rage, which POTUS says he saved MBS "a$$" by deflecting Congress investigation of Kashoggi murder. Congress may yet follow up.

There are apparently some rumors that MBS is concerned that his ascension to the throne will be challenged and that he wants to become king while Trump is still president because Trump is much more supportive than Biden. But I'll only give a little weight to these rumors, I learned not to put too much trust in grand schemes and rumors after the Kim Jong Un reporting. The simple answer is that he'll likely become king once the current one dies and that's unlikely to be in the next three months.
